elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">When metal–organic coordination polymers [M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(TTTMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (M<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Cd: <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, Zn: <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; TTTMB<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-tris(triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>BTEC<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate acid) with two dimensional layers were suspended in Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> aqueous solution, a metal–organic coordination polymer [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TTTMB)(BTEC)(μ-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) with three dimensional nets would be obtained by solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction. The direct reaction of TTTMB and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>BTEC with CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> in the absence of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> affords different crystal [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(TTTMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

When metal-organic coordination polymers [M2(SO4)(TTTMB)2(H2O)4]⋅H2BTEC⋅2H2O (M=Cd: 1, Zn: 2; TTTMB=1,3,5-tris(triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, H4BTEC=1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate acid) with two dimensional layers were suspended in Cu(NO3)2 aqueous solution, a metal-organic coordination polymer [Cu2(TTTMB)(BTEC)(μ-H2O)(H2O)4]⋅6H2O (3) with three dimensional nets would be obtained by solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction. The direct reaction of TTTMB and H4BTEC with CuSO4 in the absence of 1 or 2 affords different crystal [Cu3(TTTMB)2(H2BTEC)3(H2O)3]⋅3H2O (4).

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Through cation-exchange reaction, a Cd(II) or Zn(II) metal-organic coordination polymer with two dimensional layers can transform to a Cu(II) metal-organic coordination polymer with three dimensional nets. Visual evidence indicates that the reaction is a process of solvent-mediated reaction.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">► The structural transformation is from 2D Cd(II) or Zn(II) layers to 3D Cu(II) nets. ► The direct reaction of TTTMB and H4BTEC with CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> affords a different crystal.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic coordination polymers are currently attracting intense attention because of potential applications such as heterogeneous catalysis, physical and chemical adsorption, ion exchange, electronic and optical properties, separation processes etc. Ion exchange, one of the most intriguing properties of metal–organic coordination polymers, has been extensively studied up to date . There are two common mechanisms of solid-to-solid phase transformations upon ion exchange. One is solid-state diffusion mechanism, which refers to a single-crystal to single-crystal exchange process ; the other is solvent-mediated mechanism, which involves dissolution of the initial coordination polymer, followed by the formation and crystallization of a new coordination polymer from the solution phase . Recently, our group had reported the dissolving-exchange-crystallization processes with solvent-mediated mechanism from a tetranuclear Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> cage to a decanuclear Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> “pocket”, as well as from a 1D meso-helical chain to 2D zigzag chain . To further study the solvent-mediated mechanism, in this work, we presented a structural transformation from 2D layers [M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(TTTMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (M<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Cd: <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, Zn: <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; TTTMB<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-tris(triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>BTEC<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate acid) to 3D nets [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TTTMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BTEC)(μ-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) by solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction. However, the direct reaction of TTTMB and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>BTEC with CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> in the absence of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> affords different crystals.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► The structural transformation is from 2D Cd(II) or Zn(II) layers to 3D Cu(II) nets. ► The direct reaction of TTTMB and H4BTEC with CuSO4 affords a different crystal.

Metal-organic coordination polymers are currently attracting intense attention because of potential applications such as heterogeneous catalysis, physical and chemical adsorption, ion exchange, electronic and optical properties, separation processes etc. Ion exchange, one of the most intriguing properties of metal-organic coordination polymers, has been extensively studied up to date . There are two common mechanisms of solid-to-solid phase transformations upon ion exchange. One is solid-state diffusion mechanism, which refers to a single-crystal to single-crystal exchange process ; the other is solvent-mediated mechanism, which involves dissolution of the initial coordination polymer, followed by the formation and crystallization of a new coordination polymer from the solution phase . Recently, our group had reported the dissolving-exchange-crystallization processes with solvent-mediated mechanism from a tetranuclear NiII cage to a decanuclear CuII "pocket", as well as from a 1D meso-helical chain to 2D zigzag chain . To further study the solvent-mediated mechanism, in this work, we presented a structural transformation from 2D layers [M2(SO4)(TTTMB)2(H2O)4]⋅H2BTEC⋅3H2O (M=Cd: 1, Zn: 2; TTTMB=1,3,5-tris(triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, H4BTEC=1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate acid) to 3D nets [Cu2(TTTMB)2(BTEC)(μ-H2O)(H2O)4]⋅7H2O (3) by solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction. However, the direct reaction of TTTMB and H4BTEC with CuSO4 in the absence of 1 or 2 affords different crystals.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Light yellow crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained by hydrothermal reactions under 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals a 3D framework arising from 2D layers extended by hydrogen bonds. Only the structural depiction of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is mentioned, because <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are isostructural. Each Cd(II) is surrounded by three nitrogen atoms (N1, N4 and N7) from TTTMB, two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) from two coordinated water molecules and one oxygen atom (O3) from one sulfate, exhibiting a distorted octahedral coordination geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). Two Cd(II) atoms actually are bridged by the same oxygen (O3 and O3A). Each TTTMB adopts <ce:italic>trans,trans,trans</ce:italic>-conformation binding three Cd(II) atoms. Two of four carboxyl groups of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>BTEC are deprotonated. As depicted in the b, multi-dentate TTTMB and Cd(II) bind together to make up of a 2D layer structure. Hydrogen-bond interactions occur between the adjacent layers which arise from the coordinated waters, lattice waters and carboxylate oxygen atoms. Thus, these resulting 2D layer structures are further linked by the hydrogen-bond interactions leading to the formation of a 3D architecture (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Light yellow crystals of 1 were obtained by hydrothermal reactions under 130°C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  of 1 reveals a 3D framework arising from 2D layers extended by hydrogen bonds. Only the structural depiction of 1 is mentioned, because 2 and 1 are isostructural. Each Cd(II) is surrounded by three nitrogen atoms (N1, N4 and N7) from TTTMB, two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) from two coordinated water molecules and one oxygen atom (O3) from one sulfate, exhibiting a distorted octahedral coordination geometry ( ). Two Cd(II) atoms actually are bridged by the same oxygen (O3 and O3A). Each TTTMB adopts trans,trans,trans-conformation binding three Cd(II) atoms. Two of four carboxyl groups of H4BTEC are deprotonated. As depicted in the b, multi-dentate TTTMB and Cd(II) bind together to make up of a 2D layer structure. Hydrogen-bond interactions occur between the adjacent layers which arise from the coordinated waters, lattice waters and carboxylate oxygen atoms. Thus, these resulting 2D layer structures are further linked by the hydrogen-bond interactions leading to the formation of a 3D architecture (c).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">In an initial test for solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction, freshly prepared crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were suspended in Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> aqueous solution (0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L) and left undisturbed at room temperature. Two weeks later, light yellow crystals <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> turned opaque, meanwhile some new blue products generated (Fig. S1). Further observation reveals that new tiny blue single crystals emerged covering the surface of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Three weeks later, newly formed blue crystals replaced the initial colorless crystals. Crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have identical phenomena with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. X-ray single crystal diffraction  reveals that the newly generated crystals possess a 3D framework with the formula [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TTTMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC(μ-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). As our previous work indicated this is an infinite recurrent dissolving-exchange-crystallization process, and the solubility of coordination polymers, which depends strongly on the physical properties of the solvent, is a key factor to the process . It is clear that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can gradually dissolve in the Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> aqueous solution, which offers a prerequisite for the process of solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In an initial test for solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction, freshly prepared crystals of 1 were suspended in Cu(NO3)2 aqueous solution (0.025mol/L) and left undisturbed at room temperature. Two weeks later, light yellow crystals 1 turned opaque, meanwhile some new blue products generated (Fig. S1). Further observation reveals that new tiny blue single crystals emerged covering the surface of 1. Three weeks later, newly formed blue crystals replaced the initial colorless crystals. Crystals of 2 have identical phenomena with 1. X-ray single crystal diffraction  reveals that the newly generated crystals possess a 3D framework with the formula [Cu2(TTTMB)2BTEC(μ-H2O)(H2O)4]⋅7H2O (3). As our previous work indicated this is an infinite recurrent dissolving-exchange-crystallization process, and the solubility of coordination polymers, which depends strongly on the physical properties of the solvent, is a key factor to the process . It is clear that 1 can gradually dissolve in the Cu(NO3)2 aqueous solution, which offers a prerequisite for the process of solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contains three crystallographically unique Cu atoms (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Cu1 adopts a square-pyramidal coordination geometry with O2 in apical position and O3, O8, N4 and N7A in the mean plane (deviation from the least-square is 0.1582<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The Cu2 center is coordinated by six water molecules in octahedral coordination geometry. Cu1 and Cu2 are bridged by O2 forming an isolated Cu–O–Cu–O–Cu chain. As the geometry of Cu1 is octahedron, the unpaired electron lies on d<ce:inf loc="post">x2<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>y2</ce:inf> along the axis of octahedron, and Cu2 is located in five-coordinated environment with the unpaired electron oriented toward Cu–O. From the structure, we can see that the 2<ce:inf loc="post">Px</ce:inf> orbital of the O atoms affords exchange interaction. However, the Cu–O–Cu is 148.5° and the distance of Cu2–Cu1 is 4.671<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which mean that the magnetic orbital here is not well overlapped. Weakly antiferromagnetism is herein observed in the trinuclear copper cluster system (Fig. S2). Cu3 takes the same coordination geometry as Cu1. TTTMB, which adopts <ce:italic>cis,trans,trans</ce:italic>-conformation different from that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, links two Cu1 and one Cu3 together to make up a one dimensional (1D) chain. The chains are further linked together by Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> to form a 2D layer (b). All the carboxyl groups of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>BTEC are deprotonated. Two para-position of carboxylate groups in monodentate mode coordinate to two Cu1 center into a 1D chain. And the chains generate a 2D layer bridged by Cu–O–Cu–O–Cu groups (c). Those 2D layers interlocking together construct the 3D net framework, which is different from that of 1 (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure of 3 contains three crystallographically unique Cu atoms ( ). Cu1 adopts a square-pyramidal coordination geometry with O2 in apical position and O3, O8, N4 and N7A in the mean plane (deviation from the least-square is 0.1582Å). The Cu2 center is coordinated by six water molecules in octahedral coordination geometry. Cu1 and Cu2 are bridged by O2 forming an isolated Cu-O-Cu-O-Cu chain. As the geometry of Cu1 is octahedron, the unpaired electron lies on dx2-y2 along the axis of octahedron, and Cu2 is located in five-coordinated environment with the unpaired electron oriented toward Cu-O. From the structure, we can see that the 2Px orbital of the O atoms affords exchange interaction. However, the Cu-O-Cu is 148.5° and the distance of Cu2-Cu1 is 4.671Å, which mean that the magnetic orbital here is not well overlapped. Weakly antiferromagnetism is herein observed in the trinuclear copper cluster system (Fig. S2). Cu3 takes the same coordination geometry as Cu1. TTTMB, which adopts cis,trans,trans-conformation different from that of 1, links two Cu1 and one Cu3 together to make up a one dimensional (1D) chain. The chains are further linked together by Cu(H2O)6 2+ to form a 2D layer (b). All the carboxyl groups of H4BTEC are deprotonated. Two para-position of carboxylate groups in monodentate mode coordinate to two Cu1 center into a 1D chain. And the chains generate a 2D layer bridged by Cu-O-Cu-O-Cu groups (c). Those 2D layers interlocking together construct the 3D net framework, which is different from that of 1 (d).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The direct reaction of TTTMB and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>BTEC with CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> under hydrothermal conditions affords different product [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(TTTMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), whose crystallographic analyses confirm  that the structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is different from that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. There are three independent Cu(II) centers with the same coordination environment but different bond lengths and angles, two TTTMB with identical conformation, two H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and two half H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands in the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Each TTTMB has a <ce:italic>cis, trans, trans</ce:italic>-conformation and acts as a tridentate linker using its three triazole groups to coordinate with three Cu atoms. Two TTTMB alternately link Cu atoms together to form an infinite chain (Fig. S3). Each half deprotonated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand displaying the bi(monodentate) coordinated mode coordinates to two Cu(II) centers. Two of them connect Cu1 alternately to generate a chain, similarly, another chain is formed through Cu2 and Cu3 and another two H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTEC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands linking alternately, which forms a pair of parallel chain (Fig. S4). Further, the infinite chains and the parallel chains interlacing together contribute to the formation of 3D framework (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The direct reaction of TTTMB and H4BTEC with CuSO4 under hydrothermal conditions affords different product [Cu3(TTTMB)2(H2BTEC)3(H2O)3]⋅3H2O (4), whose crystallographic analyses confirm  that the structure of 4 is different from that of 3. There are three independent Cu(II) centers with the same coordination environment but different bond lengths and angles, two TTTMB with identical conformation, two H2BTEC2- ligands and two half H2BTEC2- ligands in the asymmetric unit of 4 ( ). Each TTTMB has a cis, trans, trans-conformation and acts as a tridentate linker using its three triazole groups to coordinate with three Cu atoms. Two TTTMB alternately link Cu atoms together to form an infinite chain (Fig. S3). Each half deprotonated H2BTEC2- ligand displaying the bi(monodentate) coordinated mode coordinates to two Cu(II) centers. Two of them connect Cu1 alternately to generate a chain, similarly, another chain is formed through Cu2 and Cu3 and another two H2BTEC2- ligands linking alternately, which forms a pair of parallel chain (Fig. S4). Further, the infinite chains and the parallel chains interlacing together contribute to the formation of 3D framework (b).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In summary, the present work reported syntheses and structures of four metal–organic coordination polymers. The Cd(II) or Zn(II) coordination polymer with 2D layer framework could turn into a Cu(II) coordination polymer with 3D net framework through solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, the present work reported syntheses and structures of four metal-organic coordination polymers. The Cd(II) or Zn(II) coordination polymer with 2D layer framework could turn into a Cu(II) coordination polymer with 3D net framework through solvent-mediated cation-exchange reaction.

</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0040" view="all">
<ce:italic>Synthesis of 1</ce:italic>: A mixture of 3CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.026<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.03<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), TTTMB(0.037<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>BTEC (0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, and the mixture was sealed and heated to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Supplementary data

    Supplementary materials.     

 Synthesis of 1: A mixture of 3CdSO4⋅8H2O (0.026g, 0.03mmol), TTTMB(0.037g, 0.1mmol), and H4BTEC (0.025g, 0.1mmol) and H2O (8mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, and the mixture was sealed and heated to 130°C for 72h. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature by 5°C per hour. Light yellow prism crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 75%. Anal. Calcd. for C46H58N18SCd2O18 (1407.95) : C 39.24, H 4.15, N 17.90, S 2.27; Found: C 39.06, H 4.05, N 17.78, S 2.21. Synthesis of 2: similar synthesis procedure except for ZnSO4⋅7H2O (0.028g, 0.01mmol). Yield: 68%. Anal. Calcd. for C46H58Zn2N18O18S (1313.94): C 42.05, H 4.45, N 19.19, S 2.44; Found: C 41.80, H 4.29, N 19.09, S 2.45. The supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2011.08.018.

Supplementary data

    Supplementary materials.     

 Synthesis of 1: A mixture of 3CdSO4⋅8H2O (0.026g, 0.03mmol), TTTMB(0.037g, 0.1mmol), and H4BTEC (0.025g, 0.1mmol) and H2O (8mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, and the mixture was sealed and heated to 130°C for 72h. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature by 5°C per hour. Light yellow prism crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 75%. Anal. Calcd. for C46H58N18SCd2O18 (1407.95) : C 39.24, H 4.15, N 17.90, S 2.27; Found: C 39.06, H 4.05, N 17.78, S 2.21. IR(cm-1, KBr): 3444(s), 3123(w), 2929(w), 1572(w), 1522(w),1454(w), 1356(s), 1285(s), 1207(w), 1135(s), 1011(w), 985(w), 881(m), 760(w), 709(w), 674(m), 640(w). Synthesis of 2: similar synthesis procedure except for ZnSO4⋅7H2O (0.028g, 0.01mmol). Yield: 68%. Anal. Calcd. for C46H58Zn2N18O18S (1313.94): C 42.05, H 4.45, N 19.19, S 2.44; Found: C 41.80, H 4.29, N 19.09, S 2.45. Crystal data for 1: C46H58N18SCd2O18, M=1407.95, monoclinic, space group P2(1)/c, a =12.023(2) Å, b =13.868(3) Å, c =17.439(4) Å, β =94.20(3) deg, v =2899.8(10) Å3, Z =2, Dc =1.578cm-3, F000 =1388, GOF =1.118, R  1  =0.0670, wR  2  =0.1984 [I>2σ(I)].

 Synthesis of 3: freshly prepared crystals of 1 or 2 were suspended in Cu(NO3)2 aqueous solution (0.025mol/L) and left undisturbed at room temperature. Two weeks later, light yellow crystals 1 or 2 turned opaque, meanwhile some new blue crystals generated. Anal.  Synthesis of 4: A mixture of CuSO4⋅5H2O (0.016g, 0.1mmol), TTTMB(0.037g, 0.1mmol), and H4BTEC (0.025g, 0.1mmol) and H2O (8mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, and the mixture was sealed and heated to 120°C for 72h.
